ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Good stuff. Pay attention to Mill, Tocqueville, Burke.

This class is a great introduction to political thought. However, it focuses on political theory at the expense of actual history. I would recommend it to a student interested in Political Science or Philosophy, but not necessarily to someone looking for a dedicated history course.

It's DS, so you know the deal. Second semester H& P is much more straight political philosophy than first semester, and there's a nicely unified train of thought and dialogue between the authors. Lebron was very friendly and led section very well - discussions were natural and free-roaming but always got where they needed to go, and his particular approach to the text makes sure to get right at the key argument (which I found super useful for DS). He also really seems to be legitimately interested in your ideas, which is a nice ego boost at 9 in the morning. Don't bother switching -- he's your guy for sure.

This is the best course of the second semester of DS. The books build on each other and have a clear arc. Prof. Lebron was very knowledgeable and helped guide us through the books to give us a good understanding of what were sometimes complicated ideas. He went for quality over quantity, preferring to focus on the difficult sections of works in class and leaving off more self-explanatory sections. He was friendly and took an interest in his students. My only complaint is he could have put more time into the class -- we sometimes ended early, he canceled a few classes, and he didn't seem to devote much time to grading the papers (the comments were scarce). Overall, I highly recommend DS H&P and I recommend Prof. Lebron.
I would recommend it. It was probably my least favorite of the three DS tracks, but valuable and interesting nonetheless.
